facts.text: On December 3, 1949, a decree was passed in favour of the respondent by the Subordinate Judge, Bankura, in West Bengal (British India).

Certificate of transfer applied for on July 27, 1950, granted on August 8, 1950, and transferred for execution on August 28, 1950 to the Court of the Additional District Judge, Morena (Gwalior State, later Madhya Bharat).
On September 25, 1950, the decree-holder took out execution in the Court of the Additional District Judge, Morena.
On judgment-debtor's objection, the application for execution was dismissed on December 29, 1950.
Appeal against dismissal allowed by High Court of Madhya Bharat at Gwalior on November 15, 1954.
Courts in Madhya Bharat governed by Indian Code of Civil Procedure as adapted by Madhya Bharat Adaptation Order of 1948.
Indian Code of Civil Procedure extended to Territories of India (Parts A, B, C States) by Act 11 of 1951 effective April 1, 1951.
S. 43 of CPC amended by Adaptation of Laws Order of June 5, 1950 with retrospective effect from January 26, 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Bankura Court had power to transfer the decree under ss. 38 and 39 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure to the Morena Court.
Whether the decree was executable under s. 43 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure as amended.
Whether the decree was a decree of a foreign Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: Court had no power to transfer the decree under s. 38 to the Court in Morena as Morena Court was not governed by Indian CPC at the time of transfer; Court in s. 38 means a Court to which Indian CPC applies (i.e., in British India).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 38, 39, 40, 42 Indian Code of Civil Procedure

petitioner_arguments.text: S. 43 inapplicable as it applies to decrees from Part B States, not Part A (British India/West Bengal); cannot read 'Part B' as 'Part A'.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 43 Indian Code of Civil Procedure as amended by Adaptation of Laws Order 1950

petitioner_arguments.text: Decree not executable under Gwalior Code s. 233 or Madhya Bharat CPC as foreign decree.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Gwalior Code s. 233; Madhya Bharat Code of Civil Procedure

respondent_arguments.text: Under ss. 38 and 39, decree could be sent to any Court (place where justice administered); relied on definition of Court.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 38, 39 Indian Code of Civil Procedure; Manawala Goundan v. Kumarappa Reddy

respondent_arguments.text: Executable under s. 43 as amended (retrospective from Jan 26, 1950); read 'in a Part B State' as 'in a Part A State'.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 43 Indian Code of Civil Procedure

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant firm not a foreigner under Foreigners Act 1946 (s. 2(a)(iii) as amended).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Foreigners Act 1946 (Act 31 of 1946, amended Act 38 of 1947)

court_reasoning.text: Court in ss. 38, 39, 40, 42 means a Court to which Indian CPC applies (British India courts); Morena Court not such at time of transfer (governed by adapted CPC but transfer power under British India CPC limited).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer ineffective as Morena not a 'Court' under Indian CPC for transfer purposes.

court_reasoning.text: S. 43 applies to decrees from Part B States; cannot amend language to read as Part A State; CPC not extended to Madhya Bharat till Act 11 of 1951.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S. 43 inapplicable to this decree before 1951.

court_reasoning.text: Foreigners Act irrelevant; execution governed by CPC provisions on transfer and applicable courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decree effectively foreign for execution in Morena under local codes.

court_reasoning.text: Manawala Goundan definition of Court not applicable here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definition pertained to different context (District Registrar).

holdings.text: Transfer of decree under ss. 38, 39 invalid as Morena Court not governed by Indian CPC as required.
S. 43 does not permit execution of Part A decree in Part B State court pre-1951.
Decree not executable in Morena under Indian CPC or local codes.

precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of 'Court' as place where justice administered not helpful for ss. 38, 39 context

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs transfer and execution of decrees; applicability limited to British India courts at relevant time

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate granting appeal to Supreme Court

statutes_cited.name: Act 11 of 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Indian CPC to Parts A, B, C States effective April 1, 1951

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Bharat Adaptation Order of 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Adapted Indian CPC for Madhya Bharat courts

statutes_cited.name: Adaptation of Laws Order of June 5, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s. 43 CPC with retrospective effect from January 26, 1950

statutes_cited.name: Gwalior Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Required suit on foreign decrees; did not permit direct execution

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Bharat Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Did not permit execution of foreign decrees

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Irrelevant to execution of decrees governed by CPC

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of High Court set aside; order of executing court dismissing execution restored.

key_quotes.text: "Court in the section means a court to which the Indian Code of Civil Procedure applies and not any Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of 'Court' in ss. 38, 39 CPC

key_quotes.text: "Section 43 has to be interpreted as it is and a Court cannot read it as if its language was different from what it actually is."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects rewriting s. 43 to apply to Part A decrees

key_quotes.text: "The transfer was ineffective for the purpose of execution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
